intro: Apargia incana, commonly known as the gray bladderwort, is a flowering plant native to North America. It is a member of the Oenotheraceae family and is characterized by its distinctive, inflated, bladder-like structures that help it capture small aquatic organisms. The plant typically grows in wetlands and shallow water areas, where it thrives in moist, sandy soils. Its flowers are usually yellow or orange, with five petals, and bloom in late summer. Apargia incana is an important part of the ecosystem, providing food and habitat for various aquatic life forms.
